translated: The Elder Paccāgāmiya’s Birth Story
“On the bank of the Sindhu River,
I was a peacock at that time;
I ate the offerings of pure devotees,
and was well-restrained in evil deeds.
I saw the dust-free Buddha,
going without faltering;
With my beak I plucked a sāl flower
and offered it to Vipassī.
Whoever has faith in the Buddha,
immovable and well-established,
By the confidence in his mind,
he does not go to a bad destination.
How welcome it was for me
in the presence of the Buddha, the best;
As a bird, I was calm,
and I planted a good seed.
For ninety-one eons,
the flower I offered;
I do not know of a bad destination,
this is the fruit of worshipping the Buddha.
Called Sucārudassanā,
they were eight with the same name;
For seventeen eons they were,
wheel-turning monarchs of great strength.
The four analytical knowledges,
I have done the Buddha’s bidding.”

original: Itthaṁ sudaṁ āyasmā paccāgamaniyo thero imā gāthāyo abhāsitthāti.
